Digital subtraction percutaneous angiography (DSA) involves the injection of a radio-opaque dye into the arterial tree by a percutaneous catheter method (Seldinger technique), usually involving the femoral artery. The images obtained are digitalized by computer and the extraneous background (bone, soft tissues, etc.) is removed to provide clearer images. The benefits of DSA are that it provides dynamic arterial flow information and can be combined with a definitive endovascular intervention when indicated. Limitations : Associated with potential complications, including bleeding, hematoma, false aneurysm formation, thrombosis, arterial dissection, distal embolization, renal dysfunction, and allergic reaction Relatively Expensive Limited to patients with concomitant intervention

Solution:

Atheromatous occlusion Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the bloodstream; it is typically the result of atheromatous occlusion of arteries.

Highyeild:

Gangrene refers to the death of macroscopic portions of tissue, which turns black because of the breakdown of hemoglobin and the formation of iron sulfide. It usually affects the distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, embolus, or arteritis). Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the bloodstream; it is typically the result of atheromatous occlusion of arteries. Wet gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may be palpated as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms, commonly in diabetic foot problems. It should be considered a surgical emergency with urgent tissue debridement or amputation required. Zone of Demarcation : A demarcation zone between the truly viable and the dead or dying tissue will eventually appear. Separation is achieved by the development of a layer of granulation tissue, which forms between the dead and the living parts In dry gangrene, if the blood supply of the proximal tissues is adequate, the final line of demarcation appears in a matter of days and separation occurs neatly and with the minimum infection Treatment : Surgical Revascularization Limb Amputation (in life-threatening sepsis) Varieties of Gangrene : Diabetic Gangrene Bedsores(Local Pressure) Frostbite (exposure to cold)

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options :- Option: A & B. Wet gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Option: C. Causes Diabetic Gangrene Diabetic gangrene is usually caused by a combination of three factors: ischemia secondary to macrovascular disease and microvascular dysfunction; peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy (PSN), which leads to trophic skin changes; and immunosuppression caused by an excess of sugar in the tissues, which predisposes to infection

Extraedge:

Other types of gangrene commonly encountered include bedsores and frostbite. Bedsores are gangrene caused by local pressure, whereas frostbite is caused by exposure to cold. Both are preventable with adequate protective measures.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenic artery The splenic artery is the most common site of the splanchnic aneurysm

Highyeild:

The splenic artery is the most common site of the splanchnic aneurysm Usually, saccular, multiple aneurysms are 20% Calcification is present in one-third and mostly situated in the distal third of the splenic artery. Four times more common in women (possible factors include multiparity, portal hypertension, arterial fibrodysplasia, pancreatitis, and, less commonly, trauma, arteritis, and septic emboli) Aneurysmal rupture in pregnancy usually occurs during the third trimester MOST COMMON site of intra-abdominal aneurysm: Aorta >Splenic artery MOST COMMON site of splanchnic artery aneurysm: Splenic artery MOST COMMON causes: Arteriosclerosis Proximal aneurysms are excised after proximal and distal ligations Mid-splenic aneurysms are excluded by proximal and distal ligations of the splenic artery and all collateral vessels. A distal or hilar aneurysm is the most common and is treated with aneurysmectomy and splenectomy

questions.text: A 60-year- male came with c/o low back ache. No h/o trauma, fever, abdominal pain, or vomiting. He has been a known smoker and alcoholic for 40 years. He is a known diabetic and hypertensive on irregular treatment. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with no tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. X-ray and ultrasound abdomen are normal. Ct's abdomen image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abdominal aortic aneurysm The abdominal aorta is dilated and enlarged, suggesting an abdominal aortic aneurysm Most common location documented: Aorta >Iliac >Popliteal >Femoral The most common site of extracranial arterial aneurysm is the infrarenal aorta Most common site of peripheral aneurysm: Popliteal aneurysm Degenerative aneurysms (caused by atherosclerosis) are MC AAA (90%)

Highyeild:

Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm An abdominal aortic aneurysm is by far the most common type of large-vessel aneurysm and is found in 2% of the population at autopsy; 95% have associated atheromatous degeneration and 95% occur below the renal arteries Types : Asymptomatic AAA : An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (Figure 61.39) in an otherwise ft patient should be considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter, measured by ultrasonography in the anteroposterior plane Investigations: CT Scan (Morphology best assessed) Treatment: Open or Endovascular aneurysm repair Ruptured AAA : Abdominal aortic aneurysms can rupture anteriorly into the peritoneal cavity (20%) or posterolaterally into the retroperitoneal space (80%). Investigations : CT Scan Management : Early diagnosis (abdominal/back pain, pulsatile mass, shock) Immediate resuscitation (oxygen, intravenous replacement therapy, central line) Maintain systolic pressure, but not >100 mmHg Urinary catheter Cross-match blood Rapid transfer to the operating room Treatment : Endovascular Repair Symptomatic AAA : These patients are most commonly present with abdominal and/ or back pain but the aneurysm is not ruptured on a CT scan. Pain may also occur in the thigh and groin because of nerve compression. Gastrointestinal, urinary, and venous symptoms can also be caused by pressure from an abdominal aneurysm Treatment: Surgery done as soon as possible Postoperative Complications : Cardiac (ischemia and infarction) and respiratory (atelectasis and lower lobe consolidation) complications are more common after open repair. Endoleak, graft migration, metal strut fracture, and graft limb occlusion are more common after EVAR. Classification of endoleaks following endovascular aneurysm repair. Type of endoleak Definition Type I Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to an ineffective seal at the proximal (la) or distal (lb) end of the stent-graft Type II Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to retrograde flow of blood from aortic collaterals, e.g. IMA, lumbar arteries Type III Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to structural failure of the stent-graft as a result of component disconnection (Illa) or stent fabric tear (Illb Type IV Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac owing to stent-graft fabric porosity Type V (endotension) Persistent filling of the aneurysm sac without evidence of types I-IV endoleak

A UK national screening program for abdominal aortic aneurysms commenced in 2009 offering an ultrasonography scan to men in their 65th year. In recent years there has been much discussion regarding the optimal way to treat an abdominal aortic aneurysm with both open surgical repair and endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) having vocal advocates in the scientific literature.

Investigations : CT Scan Management : Early diagnosis (abdominal/back pain, pulsatile mass, shock) Immediate resuscitation (oxygen, intravenous replacement therapy, central line) Maintain systolic pressure, but not >100 mmHg Urinary catheter Cross-match blood Rapid transfer to the operating room Treatment : Endovascular Repair Symptomatic AAA : These patients are most commonly present with abdominal and/ or back pain but the aneurysm is not ruptured on a CT scan. Pain may also occur in the thigh and groin because of nerve compression. Gastrointestinal, urinary, and venous symptoms can also be caused by pressure from an abdominal aneurysm Treatment: Surgery done as soon as possible Postoperative Complications : Cardiac (ischemia and infarction) and respiratory (atelectasis and lower lobe consolidation) complications are more common after open repair Endoleak, graft migration, metal strut fracture, and graft limb occlusion are more common after EVAR Peripheral Aneurysm : Popliteal artery aneurysm accounts for 70% of all peripheral aneurysms classically diagnosed in males in their seventh decade of life; 50% are bilateral. Examination of the abdominal aorta is indicated if a popliteal aneurysm is found because one-third are accompanied by aortic dilatation. Popliteal aneurysms present as a swelling behind the knee or with symptoms caused by complications, such as severe ischemia following thrombosis or distal ischemia as a result of emboli. Diagnosis: Usually confirmed with duplex scanning but the assessment of the distal vessels (with CT, MR, or DSA) is important before repair if the foot pulses are diminished or absent. Treatment: Exclusion Bypass and Inlay Repair An asymptomatic aneurysm exceeding 20mm in diameter should be considered for elective repair, to prevent future complications. Some surgeons would also offer elective repair for smaller diameters if the sac contains a thrombus, because of a perceived increased risk of distal embolization. All symptomatic popliteal aneurysms, including those in which single crural vessel embolization has occurred, should be considered for repair. Femoral Artery Aneurysm: True aneurysm of the femoral artery is uncommon. Complications occur in less than 3% so conservative treatment is generally indicated Iliac Artery Aneurysm: This usually occurs in conjunction with aortic aneurysm and only rarely on its own

questions.text: Choose the false statements among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Popliteal artery aneurysm accounts for 70% of all peripheral aneurysms

options.label: B
options.text: Its diagnosis is confirmed by a duplex scan

options.label: C
options.text: All symptomatic popliteal aneurysms need not be repaired

options.label: D
options.text: Two techniques for surgical repair may be used

questions.correct_answer: C. All symptomatic popliteal aneurysms need not be repaired
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All symptomatic popliteal aneurysms need not be repaired This is a false statement. All symptomatic popliteal aneurysms must be repaired Peripheral Aneurysm : Popliteal artery aneurysm accounts for 70% of all peripheral aneurysms classically diagnosed in males in their seventh decade of life; 50% are bilateral. Examination of the abdominal aorta is indicated if a popliteal aneurysm is found because one-third are accompanied by aortic dilatation. Popliteal aneurysms present as a swelling behind the knee or with symptoms caused by complications, such as severe ischemia following thrombosis or distal ischemia as a result of emboli. Diagnosis: Usually confirmed with duplex scanning but the assessment of the distal vessels (with CT, MR, or DSA) is important before repair if the foot pulses are diminished or absent. Treatment: Exclusion Bypass and Inlay Repair An asymptomatic aneurysm exceeding 20mm in diameter should be considered for elective repair, to prevent future complications. Some surgeons would also offer elective repair for smaller diameters if the sac contains a thrombus, because of a perceived increased risk of distal All symptomatic popliteal aneurysms, including those in which single crural vessel embolization has occurred, should be considered for repair.
